State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (Beijing) 18 Fuxue Road Beijing 102249 PR China Light olefins, especially ethylene, have been produced mainly by hydrocarbon steam cracking in recent decades. Recent studies have shown that a considerable amount of propylene and ethylene can be produced by hydrocarbon cracking on modified ZSM-5 zeolite. This article emphasizes the current research progress that acid-catalyzed paraffin cracking leads to high yields of light olefins. Propylene and ethylene were produced by the catalytic pyrolysis of different kinds of paraffin over modified ZSM-5 zeolite and summarizes the mechanism and factors influencing the catalytic pyrolysis of paraffin, i.e., various modified elements and posttreatment methods have been employed, such as rare earth elements, alkaline earth and alkali elements, transition metals, P, steaming and alkali treatments, the influences on the properties of modified ZSM-5, and the selectivity of light olefins. In addition, the effects of different factors that contain the acid properties of zeolite, the ratio of Si/Al, and process conditions on the production of ethylene and propylene are discussed, and the effects of modified elements on the catalytic pyrolysis mechanism are summarized. We look forward to the development status of the catalytic pyrolysis process and expected future development orientation. Introduction The demand and production of light olefins are much higher than the demand and production of other chemical products, as the light olefins are essential organic chemical feedstocks [1,2] and play a crucial role in chemical systems worldwide. The light olefins have been produced mainly by the steam cracking process for over half a century. Gasoline, ethylene, and diesel are the main products of the steam cracking process, and propylene is primarily produced as a byproduct. However, the steam cracking process suffers from high energy consumption due to high reaction temperatures (>800 ℃) [3] and low light olefin (ethylene and propylene) selectivity, and the distribution of light olefins is difficult to adjust [4–9]. The progress of naphtha catalytic pyrolysis to produce ethylene and propylene has attracted increasing attention from petrochemical industrial and scientific perspectives with a good deal of practical and economic consideration, low reaction temperature (600–700 ℃) [10], and high light olefin selectivity because catalytic pyrolysis reduces the energy consumption and carbon dioxide emission, increases the yields of light olefins and adjusts the distribution of the product [11–16]. Catalytic pyrolysis is still the most attractive process compared with steam cracking in the light olefin production process [17–20]. The catalytic process plays a decisive role, and the catalyst is the crucial factor in the catalytic pyrolysis reaction. Therefore, the relevant research content of the catalyst mainly introduces the zeolite. The process of using zeolites catalyzes the pyrolysis of paraffins to light olefins on the Brønsted acid (B acid) site by monomolecular (Haag-Dessau cracking) or bimolecular (classical cracking) mechanisms [21–23]. The reaction mechanism route is as follows: the protonation of the paraffin on the B acid sites of zeolite forms the pentavalent carbonium ion intermediate, which subsequently cracks to give carbenium ions through β-scission, isomerization, and deprotonation reactions to produce light olefins [20,24,25]. Currently, solid acid catalysts that include zeolites, metals supported on zeolites (ZSM-22, ZSM-5, MOR, ZSM-48, SAPO34, etc.), and mixed metal-zeolite have been extensively used to enhance the yield of light olefins in the catalytic pyrolysis of naphtha. Because of the characteristics of strong acidity, hydrothermal stability, and low hydrogen transfer activity of ZSM-5 zeolite, the special pore structure demonstrates the advantage of shape selectivity in the catalytic pyrolysis reaction [26,27]. Several related studies have been carried out on the influence of the acidity and pore structure of different zeolites on the catalytic pyrolysis of hydrocarbons in recent decades [28–30]. The comparison of the acidity and pore structure of ZSM-5 plays the most important role in light hydrocarbon conversion, product distribution, and light olefin selectivity. The different promoters of alkali and alkaline earth [31–33], rare earth [34–39], transition metals [40–43], and phosphorus [44–47] were employed to adjust the acidity of ZSM-5 and hydrothermal stability. On the one hand, the introduction of the modified element can improve the catalytic activity and the yield of propylene; on the other hand, the modified element enhances dehydrogenation cracking of feedstock and increases the ratio of propylene in the primary pyrolysis products [48]. In 2016, Sadrameli reviewed some of the experimental research work in the past decades on the production of light olefins by catalytic pyrolysis of liquid hydrocarbons using different types of catalysts and presented some of the results [10]. Blay et al. analyzed some recent advances in the understanding and development of zeolites aimed at increasing the yield of light olefins as petrochemical structural units through catalytic cracking [49]. The review by Alotibi et al. focuses on the most important and recent modifications used to improve the performance of ZSM-5 in FCC (Fluid Catalytic Cracking) processes to maximize the yield of light olefins in general and propylene in particular [50]. However, the reaction mechanism and catalysts of the catalytic pyrolysis of naphtha have not been systematically explained, especially the catalysts. The properties of the catalyst, such as acidity, pores, and modified metal properties, have an important influence on the reaction. The research hotspots focus mainly on these aspects. This manuscript systematically reviews the production of light olefins by paraffin catalytic pyrolysis technology in terms of reaction mechanism, catalysts, improved conditions, technical advantages and disadvantages, and further analyzes the key points for the future development of these technologies, which will be beneficial for relevant researchers to understand the current development status of this field. 2. Development of the catalytic pyrolysis catalysts The commonly used catalysts in the current catalytic pyrolysis reaction are divided into three main types [51]: metal oxides, zeolite catalysts, and supported catalysts. Suitable catalyst selection is the main significant point that immediately affects the yield and selectivity of ethylene and propylene ( Table 1). The influence of different catalysts on the feedstock conversion and the production of ethylene and propylene is illustrated in this section. 2.1. Catalyst of metal oxide for the catalytic pyrolysis reaction The effect of different types of metal oxide catalysts on the selectivity of light olefins was widely studied in early investigations into the catalytic pyrolysis of light hydrocarbons to produce light olefins, which are usually composed of alkaline earth metals, rare earth metals, and transition metals, such as calcium oxide, aluminum oxide, and titanium oxide. The impact of various types of metal oxides on the production of light olefins is reported in this section [53,54]. 2.1.1. The influence of metal oxide type on catalytic performance The influence of the type of metal oxide on the catalytic performance was studied. Moscow Gubojin Petroleum and Natural Gas Research Institute and the Russian Institute of Organic Synthesis jointly developed a novel potassium vanadate series of catalysts [55,56]; andalusite-corundum was used as the catalyst carrier, and manganese, vanadium, tin, iron, and other metal compounds with different chemical valences were used as the active sites. This series of catalysts showed high reaction activity and olefin selectivity, while it has superior heat resistance and a lower coking rate. The yield of light olefins is higher than 63%, and the yield of propylene is increased by 18%−20% in comparison to the conventional steam cracking process. The crystal phase effect of metal oxides has also been discussed. Lemonidou et al. [57,58] prepared calcium oxide catalysts with different 12CaO•Al2O3 catalysts that improved the selectivity of ethylene and propylene in the catalytic pyrolysis of n-hexane. To investigate the active sites where the catalyst was calcined in a hydrogen atmosphere, the treated reaction was run out of pyrolysis activity. Subsequently, they considered that the overabundance of active oxygen within the Ca12Al14O33 crystal is the possible catalytic active site. Impregnation with potassium carbonate assists in increasing the catalyst activity, improving the light olefin yield, and suppressing coke deposition [59]. A calcium aluminate sample was developed and utilized within the thermal catalytic steam cracking (TCSC) process in Germany, with the capacity to gasify coke and coke precursors, a high resistance-coking ability, a long lifetime, and excellent hydrothermal stability during the reaction. 2.1.2. Effect of the support on the properties of metal oxide catalysts The different types of supports affect the activity of metal oxides. Mjukhopadhyay and Kunzru et al. [60] investigated thermal cracking at 760–820 ℃, 0.1 MPa, using a modified alumina catalyst. The K2CO3 loading on the catalyst varies from 0 to 8.8 wt% and significantly decreases the formation of coke; at the same time, the amounts of methane, ethylene, and propylene are all decreased. Song et al. [61] researched the ability of n-paraffin catalytic pyrolysis on a MoO2 catalyst in the range of 557–640 ℃. As the paraffin selectivity decreased, which increased the olefin selectivity, a layer of MoOxCy was formed on the catalyst and suppressed the deactivation of coke deposition on the active sites of the catalyst. Jeong et al. [62] investigated catalysts using α-Al2O3 spheres with a size of 5 nm to improve the selectivity of light olefins through a naphtha catalytic pyrolysis reaction. The iron oxide/zirconia catalyst prepared by Fumoto using zirconia as a carrier accelerated the pyrolysis of heavy oil and reduced coke deposition [63]. However, due to the crystalline transformation of iron oxide, the oxide easily falls off the zirconia carrier, causing permanent deactivation [64]. The introduction of alumina increased the iron oxide catalyst stability and dispersion of alumina iron on the zirconia carrier and stabilized the iron oxide lattice structure, showing excellent and renewable cracking activity during steam cracking [65]. At the same time, the introduction of cerium oxide into the iron oxide catalyst improves the cracking of heavy oil and restrains the formation of coke [66,67]. Tomita et al. [68] proposed that alkaline earth metal oxides such as beryllium, calcium, and strontium are supported on modified alumina supports, which can effectively avoid catalyst coking and improve the selectivity of light olefins, but the reaction temperature is higher than 750 ℃. In addition to alumina, the catalyst carrier can also be selected from high-temperature resistant oxides such as zirconium, titanium, and manganese. These catalysts have excellent thermal stability and a wide range of feedstocks and have a low selectivity for light olefins. Lee et al. [69,70] perceived that metal oxide catalysts are unable to catalyze the pyrolysis of hydrocarbons, and they primarily act as heat carriers that can promote the rapid transfer of heat and increase the catalytic reaction rate within the reaction process rather than through a catalytic process. In brief, metal oxide catalysts were used for catalytic pyrolysis to produce ethylene and propylene. Although the metal oxide catalysts to a certain degree broaden the scope of application of catalytic pyrolysis feedstocks and improve the yield of ethylene and propylene, the metal oxides in the catalytic pyrolysis reaction are still the free radical mechanism. The reaction temperature is only 50 ℃ lower than steam cracking, there are many problems in the reaction of metal oxides, such as a low conversion rate and no change in the distribution of the product, and a mass of carbon dioxide causes abundant energy consumption. Therefore, the metal oxide ctalysts were gradually replaced by the zeolite catalyst because of the shape selectivity and high hydrothermal stability in the catalytic pyrolysis reaction. 2.2. Catalyst of zeolite for the catalytic pyrolysis reaction Compared with metal oxides, zeolites are aluminosilicates with a crystalline structure, diversity, excellent structural stability, unique shape selectivity, and rich acidity that can reduce the reaction temperature, increase the production of ethylene and propylene, and optimize the P/E (propylene/ethylene) ratio. [71,72] The application of zeolite in the field of catalysis is considered to be one of the most important discoveries in materials science in the 20th century [73,74] and as catalytic pyrolysis catalysts, zeolites, which primarily include HZSM-5, which is extensively used, hydrogen-exchanged beta zeolite, MCM41, SBA-15, mordenite and novel zeolites such as ITQ-2, have been extensively employed in the petrochemical industry for decades [75]. The preparation process of zeolite catalysts has been continuously developed and established, which has opened a new research direction to produce ethylene and propylene through petroleum hydrocarbon catalytic pyrolysis due to the high hydrothermal stability and shape selectivity of HZSM-5, making it more applicable than other zeolites [76]. Therefore, ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts play an important role in the pyrolysis process of petroleum hydrocarbons and have promising application prospects. The framework of zeolites has excellent hydrothermal stability under catalytic pyrolysis conditions [77]. In addition, zeolite has different acid types, and the B acid site catalyzes the pyrolysis of hydrocarbons. At the same time, the zeolite shows specific selectivity for different reactant molecules due to the microporous structure, and the structure and porosity of zeolite are vital factors to improve the yield of ethylene and propylene; consequently, it is necessary to develop a new type of zeolite catalyst that can adjust the reaction pathway of reactants. In particular, the active sites are located mostly in the micropores of zeolite. The change in pore size is closely related to the shape selectivity of the catalyst, and intermediate products of appropriate size could enter the micropores and interreact with active sites. The processes of the shape selectivity of zeolite include the intermediate product selectivity and transition state. In addition, the selectivity of the product is affected by the pore size of the catalyst. Generally, reactant intermediates with a smaller configuration can enter the pore and reach the active site, and the formed product can easily diffuse to the external surface [78–80]. The influence of the ratio of Si/Al on the framework illustrated that a higher ratio of Si/Al (>80) is beneficial to the ZSM-5 framework because the obvious influence of a lower Al amount limits the degree of dealumination, thereby improving the lattice stability. Furthermore, a higher Si/Al ratio restrains the hydrogen transfer reaction, suppresses the formation of BTX, and reduces the possibility of coke precursor formation [5]. Thus, the selectivity of the desired product can be achieved by fine-tuning the pore characteristics of zeolites. The selectivity of the product can be improved by adjusting the structure of the zeolite and the lifetime of the catalyst, which relies on the combination of shape selectivity, activity, and pore structure. From our perspective, zeolite catalysts can be modified with different promoters to improve the reactivity and selectivity of light olefins. 2.3. The modification influence on the zeolite performance ZSM-5 zeolite is one of the most widely used zeolite catalysts, and it shows excellent catalytic activity and structural stability in the petrochemical industry [81–83]. Many efforts have been made to optimize the preparation process of ZSM-5 catalysts and improve their catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. The appropriate modification method for ZSM-5 is among the extremely significant factors that influence the selectivity, and the yield of ethylene and propylene needs to be researched. The influence of different promoters on ZSM-5 and the production of light olefins is discussed in this section. 2.3.1. Modification of alkali and alkaline earth metals The acidic properties of zeolites can be modified by introducing alkaline earth metals, which decreases the strength of the acid and the number of acid sites. [84]. The larger the ionic radius with the modified element that includes Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, the more the strong acid sites are decreased. In the alkaline earth series, Ba-modified zeolite demonstrated the best selectivity of light olefins as the strongest L base. The effect of the Plank-Hirschler mechanism is inappreciable because the number of strong B acid sites decreased remarkably with the improvement in the ion-exchange extent of the Ba element. The metal hydrate cations M(H2O)n2+ and M(H2O)n3+ are formed due to the ion exchange of zeolite and metal cations, improving the degree of ion exchange, and the strength of the B acid site decreases, as verified by H MAS NMR spectra [85]. The alkali metal ion impregnation of the zeolite can partially neutralize the acidity of zeolite and adjust the dehydrogenation activity simultaneously, which is expected to improve the selectivity of the modified zeolite catalyst for propylene. Wakui et al. [84] considered the influence of modification of the alkaline earth metal in n-butane catalytic pyrolysis. The Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst was prepared by introducing strontium carbonate into the ZSM-5 synthesis solution. In comparison, alkaline earth metal modification can increase the yields of light olefins in the catalytic pyrolysis of n-butane, while the yield of aromatic products is reduced significantly because the acid sites of alkaline earth metal modification suppress the hydrogen transfer reaction compared to unmodified ZSM-5. The introduction of elements facilitates the dehydrogenation cracking reaction, the total yield of C2H4 and C3H6 obtained through Ba-HZSM-5 reaches 45%, and the Ca/HZSM-5 sample achieved the highest yield of ethylene and propylene in an oxidizing environment. Wei et al. [31] prepared a Sr-modified ZSM-5 catalyst through an ion exchange method that decreased the pyrolysis reactivity of ZSM-5 and the selectivity of light olefins in the naphtha catalytic pyrolysis process. The number of Sr-ZSM-5 zeolite acid sites decreased, the hydrogen transfer reaction was suppressed and the dehydrogenation cracking reaction was promoted [32]. Ji et al.[33] investigated the effect of the introduction of alkali metal on ZSM-5 by ion exchange with silanol groups, and Si-O(H)-Al was hydrolyzed at the same time, which accounts for the increase in Lewis (L acid) acid sites and a decrease in the number of strong B acid sites. The strength of strong acid sites was decreased, and the improvement of basic sites can improve the n-dodecane catalytic pyrolysis performance under supercritical conditions. As the number of strong acid sites is decreased and the number of basic sites is increased, the successive reaction of the light olefin and the formation of the coke precursor can be suppressed due to the reduction in the number of strong acid sites, which improves the basic sites, consequently increasing the selectivity for light olefins and reducing the formation of coke due to the variation in zeolite catalyst properties. The bimolecular reaction was suppressed, and the selectivity of light olefins was increased through the dehydrogenation reaction in the modification ZSM-5 with alkaline earth metal element. The surface basicity of modified ZSM-5 with different modified elements increased, and the readsorption of ethylene, propylene, and butene was decreased, and that is the main reason to produce more light olefins and lower aromatics [32,33,52]. 2.3.2. Modification of rare earth metals The effect of rare earth element-modified zeolites on the stability and selectivity of zeolite catalysts has been extensively explored in recent years [86–88]. The rare earth element-modified zeolite has similar chemical properties in that the external shell is filled before an inner electron shell is filled with increasing atomic number in the periodic chart. The introduction of rare earth elements by ion exchange with zeolite is the most crucial modification process in industrial catalyst preparation, and it simultaneously increases the stability of zeolite and catalytic pyrolysis activity [89]. The rare earth cation-modified zeolite improves the activity and catalytic stability of the zeolite catalyst and increases the hydrogen transfer activity due to the suppressed framework dealumination under hydrothermal conditions in the FCC reaction, which has a high reaction temperature [34]. The hydrogen transfer reaction can facilitate the hydrogenation of the produced olefins that decreases gasoline octane number; at the same time, the hydrogen transfer reaction is closely related to the coke precursor-formed deposits and the rare earth element modification associated with coke formation [88]. The rare earth modification of the ZSM-5 zeolite has a significant influence on the acidic properties. The number of strong acid sites decreased and weak acid sites improved with lanthanum-exchanged ZSM-5 zeolite, but its influence on the free pore volume and steric hindrance of zeolite can be ignored when the linear reactant crosses over the catalyst pores [90]. The acidic sites of the modified zeolite increased, except for the Gd exchanged zeolite compared with unmodified zeolite. The number of strong acid sites, weak acid sites, and total acid sites followed the following order: Sm>Nd>Pr>Eu>Ce>La>HZSM-5 >Gd, Nd>Eu>La>Sm>Ce>Pr>Gd>HZSM-5, Nd> Sm>Eu>Pr>Ce>La>HZSM-5 >Gd. The introduction of light rare earth elements exchanged with HZSM-5 zeolite adjusted the acidic properties, including the number of acid sites and type of acid. The yield of propylene and the selectivity of light olefins increased in the catalytic pyrolysis of butane, and Nd and Ce-HZSM-5 exhibited the highest yield of propylene and the total olefins [34]. The introduction of La significantly affects the properties of the ZSM-5 catalyst. Nguyen et al. [37] investigated the effect on the performance of modification of La on ZSM-5 with different loading on the vacuum gas oil pyrolysis reaction, reduced the strength of strong acid of 0.25 and 0.5 La (La/Al molar ratios) modified ZSM-5. The 0.25 La-modified ZSM-5 has the lowest number of acid sites in all samples. The acidity of the catalyst is not significant in the high La loading, and the reaction of La ions with framework aluminum can be facilitated at the lower concentration of La exchange. Liu et al. [91] researched a suite of modified HZSM-5 zeolites utilizing rare earth elements by the impregnation method. On the one hand, La, Ce, and Pr can disperse or exchange with H+ in HZSM-5 because part of the strong B acid sites in ZSM-5 turn into L acid sites, therefore increasing the L acid site concentration in modified zeolite and increasing the amount of nonframework aluminum species. In addition, the modification of the rare earth element-adjusted properties of HSM-5 and La-HZSM-5 improved the number of basic sites, decreased the strong acid concentration and improved the stability of the catalysts. Roya et al. [39] researched the influence of La-ZSM-5 on the yield of light olefins in the catalytic cracking process of propane. La modification reduced the number of strong and weak acid sites, decreased the acid strength in contrast to the parent catalyst, and reduced the selectivity of light olefins accompanied by a rapid decrease in the number of acid sites. Eduardo et al. [92] researched the role of rare earth elements in pyrolysis catalysts, and some B acid sites were formed because of the hydrolysis of some rare-earth ions. With the increasing ionic radius of rare earth atoms, the extent of hydrolysis and higher B acid sites in the zeolite increased. In the process of industrial application, rare earth element modification of zeolite catalysts increases the activity of the hydrogen transfer reaction and decreases the light olefin concentration. The acid amount of rare earth-modified HZSM-5 is listed in Table 2 with NH3-TPD measurements. The empty f orbitals of rare earth elements that are beneficial to L acid sites are formed on zeolite catalysts that provide some position in the modification of the acidity of the zeolite process. Table 3 shows the detailed Py-IR spectra results on the zeolite modified with rare earth elements. The results of all modified catalyst samples illustrated that B acid and L acid sites existed simultaneously, decreased the number of acid sites, and regulated the acid type, such as the ratio of L/B [34]. The modification of rare earth metals alters the ZSM-5 basicity due to the basic character of rare earth oxides [34]. Wakui et al. discovered the number of acid sites and strength constant in the absence and presence of 10% La loading, which illustrated that the acidic character of the zeolites did not affect the introduction of La [93]. Increasing La loading reduced the adsorption of olefins, which restrained the bimolecular reaction and increased the yield of light olefins. The modification of rare earth metals on the ZSM-5 zeolite reduces the readsorption of pyrolysis products that include ethylene, propylene, and butene, which is the main reason for the formation of higher light olefins [34]. 2.3.3. Modification of transition metals The effect of transition metal modification has been researched by a large number of scholars on the HZSM-5 zeolite to improve the catalytic pyrolysis conversion and increase the selectivity of light olefins. The certainly stable oxidation states and the variety of coordination result in the variation of d-electron numbers [77]. The introduction of the transition metal can precisely adjust the acidity and structural properties of HZSM-5. From our perspective, the L acid sites are formed because of the transition metal loaded on the HZSM-5 zeolite, simultaneously increasing the yield of ethylene and propylene. The synergistic effect of transition metal and zeolite and the role of the L acid site are not entirely explained thus far in the hydrocarbon catalytic pyrolysis reaction. The modification of transition metals can adjust the acidic character of ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts. A novel difunctional acid site may be formed because the L acid sites are formed in modified ZSM-5 [95]. The B acid sites are inclined to facilitate the cracking of the C-C bond, and the L acid sites tend to promote the breakage and desorption of C-H due to increasing the reconfiguration and desorption of hydrogen. For instance, the L acid sites increased the dehydrogenation reaction, and B acid sites improved the selectivity of light olefins [96]. The introduction of a little Cu in ZSM-5 can suppress the dealumination of the framework because of unmodified ZSM-5, and the Cu-modified ZSM-5 zeolite demonstrates a much higher total number of acid sites than the rest of the transition metals [97]. The introduction of a few Fe/Cr ions increased the ZSM-5 reactivity and selectivity in the isobutane catalytic pyrolysis process, and the total yield of light olefins was 35.6% and 56.1% on Fe/Cr-modified ZSM-5 due to the addition of Fe and Cr promoting the dehydrogenation reaction of isobutane. The majority of Fe aggregates into the larger size Fe compounds covered the ZSM-5 external surface or combined with acid sites, respectively [98]. With increasing Cr3+ loading, the weak and strong acid site density and the strength of the strong acid decreased rapidly. Increasing the amount of Fe/Cr on the HZSM-5 zeolite results in an increase in aromatic hydrocarbon selectivity and a decrease in the number of light olefins due to an increase in oligomerization and cyclization [99]. The introduction of a small amount of Cu can maintain the balance between metal dehydrogenation activity and ZSM-5 shape selectivity, as an important part of catalyst increasing the yield of light olefins in the FCC process because of hydrated Cu+ or Cu2+ preventing dealumination of the framework from the steaming process compared with parent HZSM-5 or Cr- and Ga-exchanged ZSM-5 zeolite. The overall number of acid sites of Cu-HZSM-5 exceed the remaining samples [96]. The introduction of Ni and Cu in modified ZSM-5 enhances the number of strong acid sites, possibly because H+ is replaced by Cu2+, which changes the acidity of the ZSM-5 samples [40,97,100]. The ability of metal-modified HZSM-5 to reduce coke deposition is shown in Fig. 1. The introduction of metal ions on the external surface of the HZSM-5 catalyst is favorable to decrease coke deposition and improve the lifetime because the incorporation of metal on HZSM-5 changes the original structural characteristics of HZSM-5, especially the BET surface area and total pore volume [101]. During the catalytic pyrolysis of naphtha, the reactants are converted mainly to BTX in the micropores of HZSM-5. Most of the BTX molecules diffuse out of the microcrystals as BTX products, while a small fraction of BTX is converted to coke precursors in the micropores of the zeolite where the precursor formed coke mainly on the external surface of H-ZSM-5. Only a small number of micropore openings are blocked at the initial stage of cracking, and the catalytic activity is almost retained. All of the micropore openings are blocked with increasing reaction time, leading to a significant decrease in catalytic activity. To inhibit the formation of coke, the formation of BTX and the reaction to coke must be controlled. The crystal size of H-ZSM-5 strongly influences the reaction of BTX to coke precursors compared to the acidic properties, with small crystal sizes providing shorter residence times for BTX formed within the micropores. The BTX formed within the micropores immediately separates from the micropores without converting to coke precursors, therefore decreasing the rate of coke formation [102,103]. The introduction of modified metals reduces the micropore volume of ZSM-5 zeolite, attributed to the metals blocking the pores; Momayez1 et al. prepared modified HZSM-5 catalysts with different amounts of Zr, and the pore volume of the modified catalysts was significantly decreased, attributed to the introduction of Zr blocking some of the pores [36]. Kubo et al. found that the micropore volume of HZSM-5 gradually decreased with the increase of exchange degree of Ag and Cu [104]; the micropore volume and total pore volume of Fe, Ti, Ni, and Mo modified ZSM-5 was slightly reduced compared with parent ZSM-5 [101,105]. Meanwhile, the modified metal elements have chemical functions, and the introduction of Zn, Mo, and Ti increased the L acid sites of the ZSM-5 zeolite and promoted the dehydrogenation reaction of paraffin [106]. Hou et al. investigated the effect of Zr- and Ag-modified ZSM-5 on the catalytic pyrolysis performance of n-pentane. The promotion of light olefin production by the addition of Zr compared to the parent HZSM-5 can be attributed to the enhanced interaction between the reactant molecule and the B acid site or carbenium, resulting in improved utilization of the B acid site and catalytic activity, along with approximate stability. The introduction of Ag improved the selectivity of light olefins, attributed to the Ag species on the Ag-ZSM-5 catalyst that acts as the active site for C-H bond cleavage, effectively promoting the dehydrogenation reaction and improving the selectivity of hydrogen and light olefin, while the influence of Ag modification on the elementary reaction and product distribution of paraffin catalytic pyrolysis was more significant at low temperatures (<500 °C) compared to the conventional B acid initiation mechanism. The dehydrogenation cracking reaction initiated by the Ag active site had a lower energy requirement [38,107,108]. Singh et al. researched the influence of zeolite structure over Ni- and Cu-doped ZSM-5 and found that the surface area of the zeolite decreased with increasing Cu and Ni loading; however, a change in pore volume was not observed. Therefore, we can conclude that most metals were adsorbed on the ZSM-5 external surface, while the mean pore size of the total transition metal-modified HZSM-5 zeolite increased slightly due to the blockage of micropores [40]. Andrii et al. investigated the positive influence of Fe/Co/Ni-Mo bimetallic species to improve the stability of HZSM-5, with the addition of metal to the parent ZSM-5 zeolite slightly decreasing the structural features of the surface areas, pore diameters, and pore volumes. The total experiment demonstrated a similar distribution of pore size and high relative mesoporosity due to the metal promotion compared with parent zeolites. Based on the abovementioned results, we can conclude that the introduction of the metal does not remarkably modify the texture of the ZSM-5 zeolite framework [41]. Zhao et al. observed that the introduction of Zn slightly changed the ZSM-5 crystalline structure, the partial micropores and mesopores of ZSM-5 were full of ZnO, and the partial deposited over the external surface and internal pores of Zn-modified ZSM-5; therefore, the overall pore volume and surface area decreased compared to unmodified ZSM-5 ( Table 4) [42]. The addition of Fe promoted the selectivity of light olefins and propylene and improved the stability of ZSM-5 in the naphtha catalytic pyrolysis process; however, the Cr-modified ZSM-5 catalyst did not enhance the catalytic pyrolysis activity and selectivity of light naphtha [43]. The introduction of Ag and Co on the ZSM-5 catalyst produced a similar impact by Fe in the catalytic pyrolysis of alkenes [32,109]. Previous studies have shown that the addition of various metals into ZSM-5 zeolites has resulted in diverse results. The introduction of Ga and Zn improved the yield of aromatic hydrocarbons, and it has already been confirmed that Zn-ZSM-5 is the most active catalyst to increase the selectivity of monocyclic aromatic compounds that include mainly BTX (benzene, toluene, xylene) [109]. In subsequent research, some metals showed a suppressive effect on modified ZSM-5 zeolites; however, more attention should be given to the incorporated influence of acidity, structure, and morphology of ZSM-5 to improve the stability of catalysts and the selectivity of light olefins and decrease the amount of dry gas in the catalytic pyrolysis of hydrocarbons. 2.3.4. Modification of phosphorus The addition of phosphorus is the most extensive approach to increase the stability and performance of HZSM-5 zeolites [110,111]. The researcher from Mobil first discovered that the introduction of phosphorus can improve the stability of ZSM-5 and the selectivity of light olefins, slow down the dealumination of the framework. Therefore, the introduction of phosphorus impedes the structure remarkably to the change of zeolite that increases the zeolite stability [31,111,112]. In addition, a large number of acid sites are reserved after rigorous steaming treatment, which decreases the initial acidity of ZSM-5, and the enhanced retention of framework aluminum in ZSM-5 zeolite increases the activity of catalytic pyrolysis [111]. Lercher et al. researched the influence of increased loading of phosphorus on the ZSM-5 framework aluminum, the interaction of the phosphorus and oxygen modification in the groups of bridging hydroxyl and leads to the cracking of the Al-O bonding. The aluminum hydroxyl group on the surface of the zeolite is replaced by the phosphorus hydroxyl group, and the acid strength is decreased because of the strength of Al-OH, which is stronger than P-OH [113]. Wang et al. investigated the impact of B acid sites of hydrothermal treatment of P-ZSM-5 by a variety of characterization methods. In the process of steaming treatment, new steady acid sites are formed due to the interaction between phosphorus species and silanol nests produced by dealumination. The new acid site appears to be interrelated with the position where phosphorus enters the zeolite framework through dealumination and stabilizes through certain nonframework aluminum. The addition of P into the ZSM-5 framework strengthens the stability and retards the further dealumination of the framework aluminum, and the combined effect enhances the hydrothermal stability of acid sites in P-ZSM-5 [114]. Fig. 2 shows the process of P-modified ZSM-5 and AT (alkaline treatment) ZSM-5. The P species preferentially interact with the framework and nonframework aluminum before the alkaline treatment and tend to form the excess P compound on the ZSM-5 external surface. Mesopores are formed after alkaline treatment, and the newly formed surface silanols promote the interaction of both phosphorus species and functional groups that result in diverse P parts compared to those on the microporous surface [115]. The introduction of P in HZSM-5 reduced the strength of the B acid site, and the density of weak B acid sites was enhanced because part of the strong B acid sites turned into weak B acid sites, and the total properties of the acid base barely changed [113,114,116]. Zhao et al. researched the influence of various P species on HZSM-5 acidity, and the introduction of P reduced the concentration and strength of strong sites (B and L acid) under similar desorption conditions. The number of L and B acid sites was reduced with increasing desorption temperature [117]. As proposed in the calcination process, part of the B acid sites were neutralized past loading phosphorus species, and there was conversion to a more condensed phase in the succeding hydrothermal treatment of P-modified ZSM-5, which reversibly blocked the micropores of ZSM-5. Table 5 demonstrates the acidity distribution of phosphorus-modified and unmodified HZSM-5. Fig. 3 illustrates the mechanisms by which P interacts with the HZSM-5 zeolite, following the models that have already been studied (Fig. A, B, C, D.). These latter four models seem to be unable to result in an alteration in the number of OH groups. Based on the model demonstrated in Fig. E, a group of zeolitic hydroxyls condensed with one phosphate molecule was calcined in dry air before steaming treatment, resulting in a reduction in the number of OH groups over P-modified ZSM-5, which is consistent with the consequence of Corma et al. [110]. Some zeolitic OH groups were replaced by P-OH, which improved the stability of the extraframework with high hydrothermal stability. The addition of P to HZSM-5 decreased the B acid strength, which provides a pathway to increase the production of light olefins. The synthetic effect of P-HZSM-5 increased the catalytic pyrolysis ability of C4 olefin and the hydrothermal stability under a high-temperature steaming treatment [114], which is consistent with the results of Zhao et al. The P-HZSM-5 zeolites improved the selectivity of light olefins remarkably and led to a prominent resist-coking ability in which the lifetime was over 800 h during the C4 olefin catalytic pyrolysis reaction [117]. On the one hand, the P-HZSM-5 zeolites adjusted the number of acid sites and the portion of weak acid sites in the overall acidic sites; on the other hand, the acid type was changed, such as the L/B ratio, which favors a high yield of propylene. At the same time, the results demonstrated that newly formed basic sites on the external surface of P-modified HZSM-5 zeolites suppressed the adsorption of light olefins and decreased the production of BTX and coke precursor. The introduction of P can adjust the basic and acidic properties of HZSM-5, which improves the performance of the catalytic pyrolysis of hydrocarbons and provides a new strategy for the engineering of novel catalysts to improve the selectivity of light olefins, especially propylene [44]. 2.3.5. The influence of surface modification, steaming, and alkali treatment on the properties of zeolite The unique microporous properties of ZSM-5 demonstrate the excellent selectivity of light olefins in the catalytic pyrolysis process of hydrocarbons. However, the pore size of ZSM-5 is only 0.55 nm, which restricts the reactant product into the micropore, decreases the accessibility of the acid sites of the internal surface, and suppresses the catalytic pyrolysis rate of hydrocarbons [121–123]. The introduction of a nanostructure shortens the diffusion path of the intermediate products and enhances the capacity to resist coke deposition on the external surface [124,125]. In the process of zeolite synthesis, some researchers employ quaternary ammonium surfactants as template agents and utilize their guiding effect to limit the growth direction of zeolites that introduce nanostructures. Ryo et al. successfully synthesized ZSM-5 zeolite nanosheets that provide highly ordered and interconnected hierarchical pores using diquaternary ammonium surfactants that act as a microporous template and a structure-directing agent at the same time, forming an MFI framework at the hydrophilic double quaternary ammonium group and inhibiting the growth of crystals at the hydrophobic end of the long-chain alkyl group, forming a flake structure that extends on the ac plane and alternately distributes micropores and a mesoporous layer along the b axis [126]. Hao et al. used diquaternary ammonium surfactant as a template to synthesize nano ZSM-5 zeolite with different thicknesses, which are used in the catalytic cracking of n-heptane to extend the catalyst lifetime and improve the selectivity of light olefins [127]. Due to its small crystal size, high external specific surface area, and short diffusion path, nano zeolites can improve mass transfer and diffusion ability, reduce diffusion resistance and inhibit pore coking, and exhibit excellent resistance coking ability and stability in hydrocarbon catalytic pyrolysis reactions [128]. However, the preparation process of nanostructure zeolites is complicated compared with traditional methods of structural modification, and the inherent microporous structure of ZSM-5 zeolites is destroyed, resulting in decreased crystallinity and shape selectivity, which indicates that the state of zeolite crystals affects the diffusion of reactants during catalytic pyrolysis [129–131]. At present, surface modification methods are widely used, including chemical vapor deposition (CVD), surface etching, and chemical liquid deposition (CLD), to adjust the structural properties. Chemical liquid surface modification is one of the simplest and easiest surface modification methods and is convenient and beneficial to mass transfer [132]. On the one hand, the surface modification does not affect the essential pore structure of ZSM-5; on the other hand, to maintain the original structure and performance and improve the external surface area, the formed surface environment is suitable for the attachment of reactant and promotes the mutual diffusion and mass transfer of the product on the modified ZSM-5 external surface. The steaming treatment of ZSM-5 zeolite is possibly the oldest modifying treatment method that is usually used to adjust the acidity and regulate the pore structure of the catalysts. The ZSM-5 catalyst undergoes dealumination during steaming treatment at over 500 ℃ and hydrolyzes the Al–O bond on the ZSM-5 framework, which effectively removes the aluminum of the framework. The portion of the framework can be dissolved or adjusted, forming a mesoporous system, and introduction to the microporous zeolite probably improves the transport of the product of the reactant and conversion of correlatively large molecules that may be in the feedstocks. Increasing both the Si/Al ratio of the framework and the stability of ZSM-5 zeolites and the treatment process decreased the acid strength of the samples. The nonframework aluminum was formed by dealumination that possibly blocked the internal and external pores, therefore reducing the surface area and pore volumes. Additionally, aluminum can be dissolved and removed from the framework of zeolites under suitable conditions by using a solution of inorganic-organic acids to improve the connectivity of ZSM-5 micropores [133–135]. Alkaline treatment is also commonly used to adjust the structure of zeolite by different concentrations of base solutions, which can selectively remove part of the silicon of the zeolite framework and introduce the mesoporous structure as a result of the effect of desalinization over different alkaline solutions ( Fig. 4). The traditional method is to treat zeolite catalysts with conventional inorganic alkaline solutions (NaOH), and the solution of the organic base has a lower solubility for silicon species compared with the former. Organic hydroxide is less selective for silicon extraction, such as higher Al leaching compared to the inorganic solution observed, and thus, a higher ratio of Si/Al in the mesoporous zeolites is obtained. The catalytic performance of hydrocarbons was influenced by the diverse types of Al species in the different base solution-treated HZSM-5 zeolites. In the process of practical application, there is a high cost in desilication in the presence of an organic base compared with the inorganic base solution, despite the avoidance of ion exchange [136,137]. Ogura et al. researched the influence of NaOH treatment process conditions on ZSM-5 zeolite (Si/Al=40), and a mesoporous structure was formed during the first treatment. The influence of the base solution concentration and treatment time on the acidity and structure of the ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst was also researched, showing that the treatment time and concentration of the base solution affect the formation of mesopore volume and that dealumination does not affect the acidity of ZSM-5 zeolites because it is determined mainly by the amount of framework aluminum [138,139]. Groen et al. found that the Si/Al ratio of zeolites has an important impact on the process of alkali treatment desiliconization with different Si/Al ratios (5–1000). The content of aluminum in ZSM-5 with a low Si/Al ratio is higher than the content of aluminum in ZSM-5 with a high Si/Al ratio, which restrains the removal of framework Al and affects mesopore information [133,138]. A large number of mesopores were formed, a wide particle size distribution was observed, and a low surface area of mesopores at the Si/Al ratio was higher than 200 in the alkali treatment process [140]. The ZSM-5 zeolite was first desiliconized by alkali treatment, and then aluminum was removed with a strong acid solution. Hierarchical ZSM-5 was obtained, which increased the external specific surface area and the utilization degree of the acid sites of ZSM-5 due to the introduction of intercrystalline mesopores. At the same time, intercrystalline mesopores shorten the diffusion path of microporous channels and partially inhibit the secondary reaction of target products, resulting in an increase in the selectivity of light olefins [141]. 2.4. Summary and prospect of ZSM-5catalyst preparation According to the abovementioned modification of elements (alkali metals, transition metals, rare earth metals, and phosphorus) on HZSM-5, we concluded that the product distribution was flexible and could be obtained at a suitable strength and density of acid. Zeolite pyrolysis catalysts are beneficial for producing more propylene, and the reaction mainly follows the carbenium mechanism. The protolytic cracking mechanism plays a vital role in the production of light olefins. For metal oxide catalysts, the active components of the catalyst, carriers, and auxiliary agents are the most important factors affecting catalysis; for zeolite pyrolysis catalysts, the pore structure, crystal size, and acidity of the zeolites are the most significant factors. A suitable zeolite must be selected or modified according to the characteristics of the feedstocks so that the prepared catalyst has the optimal pore structure distribution that has a significant impact on the pyrolysis performance. The development of efficient pyrolysis catalysts should focus on the following aspects: to promote the monomolecular cracking reaction, the catalyst must have high acid strength, low B acid concentration, and appropriate L acid concentration. The acid properties are adjusted mainly by adjusting the ratio of Si/Al, calcination, steaming treatment, and acid washing. In terms of pore structure, the catalyst pore size should be close to the size of reactant molecules or carbenium, and the catalyst should have a hierarchical pore structure to promote the mass transfer process. At the same time, the crystal size should be small to reduce the internal diffusion resistance and apparent activation energy, shorten the diffusion path, suppress the bimolecular reaction, and improve the conversion and propylene yield. 3. Catalytic pyrolysis mechanism in zeolites The mechanism of the catalytic pyrolysis reaction usually refers to the carbenium mechanism that occurs in the presence of a zeolite. The use of zeolite reduced the reaction activation energy and temperature and increased the conversion of feedstocks [24,25], including naphtha [142], catalytic pyrolysis gasoline, heptane [59], and C4 hydrocarbons [143]. In this section, the mechanism of paraffin catalytic pyrolysis into light olefins and the influencing factors are summarized and discussed. 3.1. Catalytic pyrolysis mechanism of paraffin on the zeolites The carbenium mechanism is dominant in the paraffin catalytic pyrolysis reaction in the presence of zeolite catalysts. However, the free radical mechanism will coexist due to the high reaction temperature (>600 ℃) [144]. In general, the carbenium mechanism is dominant in the presence of zeolite catalysts [145], including two types: the monomolecular mechanism (Haag-Dessau cracking mechanism) and the bimolecular mechanism (classical cracking mechanism) [146–148]. In the presence of bimolecular mechanism ( Fig. 5), the pyrolysis reaction occurs when the branched secondary and tertiary alkylcarbenium obtained from the feedstock molecules is cracked into smaller alkylcarbenium and olefins by a single β-scission reaction ( Fig. 6.). The monomolecular mechanism is divided into three main steps: protonation, cracking, and deprotonation. Haag and Dessau [149] first proposed the monomolecular reaction mechanism. In the presence of an acidic zeolite catalyst, paraffin molecules are protonated to form a carbonium transition state and then to form light paraffin, for instance, CH4 and C2H6, carbenium, and hydrogen, through cracking of C-C or C-H bonds. Then, carbenium will undergo a β-scission reaction and provide a proton to the zeolite, which is converted into a light olefin. For the bimolecular mechanism, paraffin molecules form carbenium by obtaining positive hydrogen ions or losing negative hydrogen ions. The resulting carbenium will undergo further reactions, such as alkylation, hydrogen transfer, isomerization, and cracking, to form light olefins [25, 149–151]. In addition to the above two reaction mechanisms, a chain reaction mechanism was proposed, which consists of three primary steps: chain initiation, chain transfer, and chain termination. The initiation step of the paraffin catalytic pyrolysis reaction consists of three types: olefin initiation, L acid initiation [152–159], and B acid initiation [156–159]. The initiation mechanism of B acid plays a key role and explains the product distribution in the paraffin pyrolysis reaction. The superiority of the chain reaction mechanism is that the chain reaction simplifies the catalytic pyrolysis reaction process, and the number of reactant molecules is not considered. The chain reaction has certain advantages for the prediction of reaction kinetic chain length, the establishment of reaction kinetics, and the analysis of the ratio of paraffin to olefins in the product. Therefore, the process of actually exploring the mechanism of the catalytic pyrolysis reaction on account of the reaction network of zeolite catalyzed is more complicated, the currently reported mechanism is focused mainly on the initiation step, it lacks a comprehensive analysis of the entire catalytic pyrolysis reaction network, and it is difficult to qualitatively correlate the cracked product with the elementary reaction, the analysis of the influence of various condition factors on the catalytic pyrolysis of paraffin is still at the macro product level, which cannot provide sufficient theoretical direction for catalyst design and reaction process optimization. Combining the mechanism of B acid initiation, paraffin model molecules were employed to investigate elementary reactions, including monomolecular cracking, hydrogen transfer reaction, β-scission, deprotonation, and related side reactions [108,160]. Zeolites with different structures [161], Si/Al ratios [162,163], and reaction conditions [164,165] were selected to investigate their influence on elementary reactions, summarize the main elementary reactions of zeolite-catalyzed paraffin pyrolysis, simplify the reaction network, and combine the target product with the qualitative association of elementary reactions [166–168]. Employing element modification and high-temperature regeneration [169] methods can selectively control the elementary reaction of paraffin pyrolysis and qualitatively analyze the impact on the pyrolysis performance, investigate the influence of the control elementary reaction on the ultimate product, the pyrolysis conversion, and the stability of the catalyst, establish a qualitative correlation between the catalyst, elementary reaction, and pyrolysis performance, and provide theoretical guidance for the design of catalytic pyrolysis catalysts with good cracking activity, the high selectivity of light olefins and the high resistance of coke deposition. 3.2. The main determining factor of the reaction path The type of catalyst and operating conditions directly affect the abovementioned reaction mechanism. The carbenium mechanism and free radical mechanism coexist under catalytic pyrolysis reaction conditions when a zeolite catalyst is used, and the carbenium mechanism plays a key role at a low reaction temperature (<600 ℃) in the catalytic pyrolysis reaction [170–173]. The physicochemical properties (such as shape, pore size, acidity, promoter type, and Si/Al ratio) of the zeolite catalyst directly affect the reaction mechanism. The monomolecular mechanism is conducive to the production of ethylene and propylene, while the bimolecular mechanism is conducive to hydrogen transfer and aromatization reactions and suppresses the production of light olefins. At the same time, in the presence of a low concentration of olefins [174], low reactant partial pressure, and high temperature under reaction conditions with low conversion [175–178], the monomolecular mechanism is predominant in medium zeolites (such as ZSM-5) with a high ratio of Si/Al [4,25] and a low density of proton sites [177,179]. The bimolecular mechanism is dominant under the reaction environment of low reaction temperature, high acid density, and large pore zeolite (such as Y zeolite) [161,180]. The production of light olefins was improved because of the effect of ZSM-5 zeolite shape selectivity affecting the performance of catalyst from two aspects: one is to select the shape of the reactants, such as the linear, single-branched chain structure in the micropores [181], the second is that the shape-selection of the transition state in zeolite include inhibiting the transition state was formed in a hydrogen transfer reaction and formed coke. The introduction of mesopores makes ZSM-5 zeolite have a superior catalytic performance that can strengthen the mass transfer of ZSM-5 and improve the diffusion efficiency. The light olefins can be desorbed in time and diffuse to the bulk phase, reduce the secondary reaction and increase the selectivity of light olefins, and the formed coke precursor can quickly diffuse out of the pores, slow down the formation of coke and improve the catalyst lifetime [182–184]. However, the introduction of the mesoporous structure into the ZSM-5 zeolite is usually at the expense of part of the microporous structure and influences the distribution of the acid sites [185–187]. How to equilibrate the ratio of microporous and mesoporous structures and the impact on acidic sites are important considerations. The strength and local environment of the ZSM-5 acid sites are strongly correlated to the different reactions through various routes and can effectively improve the production of light olefins, especially propylene, and has high hydrothermal stability. The activity of the B acid site in the ZSM-5 zeolite was intensely affected through the reaction rate-controlling step and the shape and size of zeolite micropores. The high B acid site density decreased the reaction energy barrier of the hydrogen transfer and improved the reaction rate, and the desorption of the intermediate species played a key role at the rate-limiting step in the paraffin dehydrogenation reaction. This result was closely related to the stabilization of these products, which relied on the B acid site environment of the zeolite framework and the ratio of Si/Al. Therefore, adjusting the state of the ZSM-5 zeolite can improve the stability of the intermediate species, reduce the hydrogen transfer reaction rate and increase the yield of light olefins. The light olefins will decrease due to the hydrogen transfer reaction and secondary pyrolysis reaction during the reaction process. The formed carbenium is likely to undergo a hydrogen transfer reaction with other hydrocarbon molecules adsorbed on the closed acid site, and light olefins can also be converted to alkanes, BTX, and coke precursors, resulting in a reduction of light olefins. The faster pyrolysis rate and strong competitive adsorption capacity of light olefins are inclined to secondary pyrolysis reactions to produce smaller olefin species, increasing the yield of light olefins. Therefore, to produce more ethylene and propylene, the hydrogen transfer reaction should be suppressed while strengthening the secondary pyrolysis reaction of macroolefins to produce more ethylene and propylene. Generally, reducing the acid density of zeolite and increasing the acid strength are used to suppress the hydrogen transfer activity and increase the temperature to restrain the secondary reaction. At the same time, restraining the hydrogen transfer reaction is beneficial to decrease coke deposition and improve the catalyst lifetime. To achieve high-efficiency conversion of paraffin and improve the production of light olefins, the design and preparation of pyrolysis catalysts play a critical role. The protonation cracking reaction should be promoted, the prepared catalyst should have a small crystal size that reduces diffusion resistance of intermediate products, a hierarchical pore structure suppresses the coking deposition, high acid strength improves the conversion, low B acid concentration restrains the bimolecular cracking reaction, and appropriate L acid concentration synergistic effect with B acid facilitates the initial reaction proceeding, but too low B acid strength to reduce the paraffin conversion rate. Therefore, the acid concentration to acid strength ratio of the zeolite catalyst should be kept in a reasonable range to achieve high conversion and propylene yield in the paraffin catalytic pyrolysis reaction. 4. Development status of catalytic pyrolysis technology The processes of catalytic pyrolysis using light hydrocarbons as feedstock include mainly the C4 component, and naphtha is the most promising route to produce light olefins at present. The former includes the OCP (Olefin Cracking Process), Propylur process, Superflex process, the MOI process developed by Exxon-Mobil, and the OCC (Olefin Catalytic Cracking) process developed by the Sinopec Shanghai Petrochemical Research Institute. The latter includes mainly the ACO (advanced catalytic olefin) process jointly studied by KBR/SK corporation. In this section, the development status of the catalytic pyrolysis process is discussed, the characteristics of each process are summarized, and prospects for the development direction of catalytic pyrolysis technology are discussed. In Table 6, P and E are defined as propylene and ethylene. In Table 6, the description section of the catalyst regeneration, the recycling means that the reaction process can be operated continuously, no is the opposite. The process of MOI, ACO, and Superflex using a fluidized bed or riser reactor can realize continuous regeneration and recycling of the catalyst. The difference from the former is that other reaction processes using fixed-bed reactors cannot achieve continuous operation. When the catalyst undergoes coking deactivation, it is necessary to replace fresh or regenerated catalyst or switch to another reactor to achieve the normal progress of the reaction. Table 7 describes the industrialization of some of the technologies in Table 6 in recent years. The technologies mentioned in Table 6 are still the main technologies, while some new catalytic pyrolysis technologies have been developed, which are not reported to be industrialized or commercialized. Saudi Aramco, JX Nippon Oil, and KFUPM developed HS-FCC (High-Severity Fluid Catalytic Cracking), which employs a high temperature (580−620 °C) downer reaction working at a short residence time (0.5−1 s) to minimize thermal cracking and to avoid the saturation of the generated light olefins to paraffins by subsequent hydrogen transfer reactions. The process (whose units are built by Axens) also operates at a very high catalyst/oil ratio compared with a conventional FCC and uses a proprietary catalyst developed by JX [199,200]. In addition, the related technologies are MILOS from Shell, MAXOFIN from KBR, Flexible Dual-riser Fluid Catalytic Cracking (FDFCC) developed by Sinopec RIPP, and Double Riser FCC designed by Petrobras [49]. Although the current catalytic pyrolysis technology has made great progress in past decades, there are still some shortcomings that need to be resolved. From the point of view of the catalytic pyrolysis reaction, the main factors that affect catalytic pyrolysis are the composition of the feedstocks, the type of reactor and catalyst, and the operating conditions. The larger ratio of H/C and the characteristic factor k of the feedstock are beneficial to increase the selectivity of light olefins in catalytic pyrolysis, and the order of the yield of light olefins is formed: paraffin > cycloparaffins > isoparaffins > aromatics. The type of reactor is a major factor affecting the production distribution, and the reactors used include mainly the fixed bed, fluidized bed, downer bed, riser, and tubular pyrolysis furnace. The riser reactor was extensively used in the catalytic pyrolysis process, but there are problems with a long reaction time and easy deactivation of the catalyst. The descending bed reactor has the advantages of uniform distribution and small axial back mixing due to the short gas-solid contact time. The design of a new type of catalytic pyrolysis reactor is the key development direction and research focus of catalytic pyrolysis reactions. According to variations in catalytic pyrolysis feedstock and light olefin market demand, catalytic pyrolysis technology is required to satisfy the shortcomings of market demand. On the one hand, catalytic pyrolysis should provide the requirements of light olefin (ethylene and propylene) production; on the other hand, naphtha as a feedstock to achieve highly efficient conversion and a controllable ratio of propylene to ethylene is also required. Therefore, the traditional thermal cracking process will gradually be transformed into catalytic pyrolysis, for instance, ACO ( Fig. 7) can effectively produce light olefins, reduce the energy consumption in the reaction process, and adjust the distribution of ethylene and propylene [201–203]. Most of the currently used steam cracking devices and units can be used as a catalytic pyrolysis process to reduce the expenditure of equipment investment, and the novel process technology has great potential for industrialization and commercialization. In comparison to the steam cracking reaction, regardless of the adaptability of feedstocks or the flexibility of product yield, energy consumption, operation, and product distribution, the social and economic benefits of catalytic pyrolysis are very significant and have prominent application prospects. As steam cracking has become more mature and perfect, it still takes time for catalytic pyrolysis to become a market-leading process. At the same time, catalytic pyrolysis should strengthen research in the following aspects: develop catalysts with high selectivity and lifetime requirements, reduce the coke deposition rate of the catalysts, increase the antipoisoning and continuous regeneration of the catalysts, focus on the improvement of existing processes, catalysts, engineering and production technology and the transformation of existing equipment, and develop novel zeolite preparation and modification technology to realize the multifunctionality of active components. 5. Conclusions and prospects At present, with the development of market demand for light olefins, the annual demand for propylene/ethylene is increasing. Light olefins originate mainly from the steam cracking process at this stage that produces 95% ethylene and 61% propylene worldwide, which has the shortcomings of a high reaction temperature, low propylene selectivity, and difficulty adjusting the ratio of propylene/ethylene, and it is difficult to satisfy the market demand for light olefins. The catalytic pyrolysis process reduces the reaction temperature by 200 °C, broadens the range of feedstock sources that include straight-run naphtha, raffinate oil, hydrogenated crude gasoline, MTO gasoline, Fischer-Tropsch naphtha, MTO mixed C4, etc., and improves the conversion of feedstock due to the introduction of ZSM-5 with shape selectivity and microporous structure. By adjusting the chemical properties of ZSM-5, an improvement in the light olefin yield of 7%− 10% and an increase in the propylene/ethylene ratio to 1.8–1 were observed. The different modification methods and the number of loadings affect the properties of ZSM-5 catalysts and the distribution of product, and the regulation of acid properties includes the employment of different modified elements. The introduction of alkali and alkaline earth metals reduces the acid strength, increases the surface basicity and facilitates the dehydrogenation reaction to increase the selectivity of ethylene and propylene; the introduction of transition metals modifies the acid type and B acid strength and promotes the dehydrogenation reaction; the introduction of rare-earth metals reduces the acid strength and distribution; the introduction of phosphorus not only modifies the chemical properties of zeolite but also improves the hydrothermal stability; ZSM-5 with high Si/Al ratios (>80) restricts the removal of framework aluminum due to its low aluminum content while suppressing hydrogen transfer reactions and the formation of BTX. The regulation of pore properties included alkali treatment and steaming treatment, which introduced the mesoporous structure, promoted the diffusion of products, and reduced coke deposition. However, there are still some problems in the large-scale production of light olefins utilizing catalytic pyrolysis. One is the high coking rate of the catalyst, and the other is that the yield and selectivity of light olefins are lower than the theoretical value. There is space for a further increase in the yield of ethylene and propylene, so new requirements for catalyst design and reaction operation conditions are proposed. In the next development direction, zeolite catalysts with hierarchical pore structures should be developed to reduce the coking rate of catalysts, and at the same time, the synergistic effect between the active sites and the zeolite should be adjusted to optimize the acid properties of the catalyst to facilitate the protolytic cracking reaction and suppress the hydrogen transfer activity for catalysts and catalytic pyrolysis to be used in practice. Relevant research is necessary: evaluation of catalyst performance in the pilot plant and optimization of regeneration methods to improve the yield and selectivity of light olefins using different hydrocarbon feedstocks. The catalytic pyrolysis process can unite the existing refineries and chemical plants, which is conducive to the formation of refinement and chemical integration and builds a bridge between the refinement and chemical industries. On the one hand, the former device can provide the required feedstocks of olefins and produce ethane, propane, etc., which can be used as feedstocks for steam cracking to further produce light olefins. On the other hand, the decommissioned steam cracking unit can be transformed into a catalytic pyrolysis unit, which provides a favorable route for equipment renewal and utilization. According to the reasons mentioned above and in the context of carbon neutrality and carbon peak, catalytic pyrolysis, such as ACO, will gradually occupy a larger portion of the production of light olefins compared to steam cracking. ACO can effectively produce light olefins, lower the reaction temperature, and change the product distribution. Most of the equipment and units currently used in the steam cracking process can be used in catalytic pyrolysis reactions; therefore, the utilization and commercialization of different hydrocarbon feedstocks to produce light olefins through catalytic pyrolysis will attract increasing attention in the next decade. coredata.dc:description: Light olefins, especially ethylene, have been produced mainly by hydrocarbon steam cracking in recent decades. Recent studies have shown that a considerable amount of propylene and ethylene can be produced by hydrocarbon cracking on modified ZSM-5 zeolite. This article emphasizes the current research progress that acid-catalyzed paraffin cracking leads to high yields of light olefins. Propylene and ethylene were produced by the catalytic pyrolysis of different kinds of paraffin over modified ZSM-5 zeolite and summarizes the mechanism and factors influencing the catalytic pyrolysis of paraffin, i.e., various modified elements and posttreatment methods have been employed, such as rare earth elements, alkaline earth and alkali elements, transition metals, P, steaming and alkali treatments, the influences on the properties of modified ZSM-5, and the selectivity of light olefins. In addition, the effects of different factors that contain the acid properties of zeolite, the ratio of Si/Al, and process conditions on the production of ethylene and propylene are discussed, and the effects of modified elements on the catalytic pyrolysis mechanism are summarized. We look forward to the development status of the catalytic pyrolysis process and expected future development orientation.
coredata.dc:title: The advance in catalytic pyrolysis of naphtha technology using ZSM-5 as catalyst
